Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Spencer J. Ingley is, "Can species capture beneficial traits and expand their ranges through hybridization?" The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences (NCMNS) and the sponsoring scientists are Karin Pfennig (UNC) and Bryan Stuart (NCMNS).

Can hybridization facilitate the expansion of a species' niche? The fellowship research addresses this fundamental question through the use of historic museum collections and data from behavioral studies. Several lines of evidence suggest that hybridization with the New Mexican spadefoot toad facilitated the spread of the Plains spadefoot toad into the American Southwest via the capture of adaptive developmental traits. Using morphological signatures of development speed and ancient DNA techniques, the role of hybridization in developmental evolution, and its implications for range expansion, are being investigated. Specimens from several museum collections, including NCMNS, Sam Noble Oklahoma Museum of Natural History, University of Kansas Biodiversity Institute and Natural History Museum, Texas Natural History Collections, and the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, make this research possible and provide a full range of present and past evolutionary and ecological dynamics.

Training goals include learning new data acquisition and analytic tools, including ancient DNA extraction and analysis. Career development activities include science communication to both public and scientific audiences. Broader impacts fall into two categories. First, a robust plan is being implemented to increase participation of underrepresented groups in science and outreach to the public through existing programs, i.e., Darwin Day.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biologists have long sought to understand why certain species are found where they are. This fundamental question, of what drives the formation and changing of species’ ranges, has broad reaching implications in fields as varied as ecology, behavior, virology, and epidemiology. Of particular interest in recent years is the impact of behavior on a species’ range. Can the choices of an individual member of a species influence where the species as a whole is distributed? My project aimed to address this question by assessing the role of novelty seeking behavior in driving changes to a species’ range. 


For this work, I focused on a unique group of amphibians, the Spadefoot Toads (genus Spea). These toads are found in a variety of habitats across the US, from wetlands in the Great Plains and the American South, to the deserts of the American Southwest and into Mexico. One species, the Plains Spadefoot toad, has recently expanded its range from the Great Plains region into the deserts of Texas, Arizona, and New Mexico, and appears to have been able to do this in part by hybridizing with a closely related species that is adapted to living in the desert. By hybridizing, the Plains Spadefoot can help ensure that its tadpoles will develop quickly enough to escape the highly ephemeral desert ponds in the Southwest. Thus, this range expansion appears to have been facilitated by the decisions of individual toads to hybridize with a member of another species. This hybridization behavior, which could be viewed as a dysfunctional behavior in many situations, appears to be key in this example of shifting ranges. 


To expand on this research, I evaluated the role of individual level variation in behavior, sometimes referred to as ‘animal personality’, in driving this range expansion. Do some individuals tend to be more prone to engage in dysfunctional behavior than others? And can this impact broad scale ecological patterns in nature? I focused on an important axis of personality, novelty seeking behavior, because it has broad reaching implications for individual decision making and can influence the likelihood of an individual engaging in risky or compulsive behavior. In the Plains Spadefoot toad, I found that populations increased in their level of novelty seeking behavior as they moved away from the ancestral range and into the desert, suggesting that these behaviors could influence this broad pattern of expansion. Furthermore, I found that more novelty seeking individuals were more likely to engage in hybridization behavior in the desert environment, suggesting that novelty seeking phenotypes might be better able to assess their environmental conditions and make a decision that is ideal for a given situation. This finding has important implications for understanding how the decisions of an individual can scale up to drive species level changes. 


Beyond the research, funding for this project provided countless growth opportunities for myself and those I mentored and allowed me to progress to the next stage of my career. I was able to conduct mentored research and outreach with undergraduate students and graduate students from numerous underrepresented groups, and I honed my skills as a researcher, educator, and scientific communicator. I participated in numerous outreach programs to help promote public understanding of science (for example, the Darwin Day program at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, attended by tens of thousands of local families), and help increase access to science in underrepresented groups (for example, through work with the Girls Advancing in STEM program).
